Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Distributed Sensemaking: Making Sense of the Web Together

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop web-based knowledge-building environments for the collaborative creation of information landscapes: interactive visualizations that support the sensemaking individuals engage in online, and capture their efforts for the benefit of others who come after them. To guide and motivate the design of these environments, the research builds on theories of sensemaking, which describe the nested and parallel loops through which individuals seek out, analyze, and understand information, grounded in a rich history from organizational behavior, social and cognitive psychology, and human-computer interaction. It will extend theories of individual sensemaking to the situation in which an individual's processing of information for themselves is consumed by others, whose processing in turns improves the sensemaking of those coming after them - what can be called the "distributed sensemaking cycle."

Examining distributed sensemaking in a way that is both rigorous and environmentally valid is a challenging prospect, so this project will take a multi-stage approach involving laboratory studies to characterize the distributed sensemaking process and iteratively develop interfaces; "virtual lab" experiments harnessing crowdsourcing to evaluate these processes and interfaces at a larger scale while bootstrapping the system's value; and controlled field trials to test theories and interfaces in environmentally valid settings.

In order to capture the benefits and costs to both the producer and the consumer, the research will employ an experimental framework that elicits both of their perspectives. The general approach involves the producer using an interface for a sensemaking task and the consumer doing the same task but starting with the results of the producer's work. This approach will iteratively develop interfaces that help individuals forage for information, integrate the results of their foraging into information landscapes, and convey the judgments, decisions, and work they engaged in during the process to others.

The results of this research will advance scientific understanding across a variety of domains, including sensemaking, collaboration, schema induction, and interface design. The research has the potential to improve the efficiency of knowledge work, the training and practice of scientists, and the effectiveness of education. The tools developed in this research will be incorporated and evaluated in educational practice, and will become the center of a community linked to several existing knowledge bases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People are constantly engaged in making sense of the world by searching online: patients try to make sense of their symptoms; consumers try to make sense of which camera to buy; scientists try to make sense of the literature in an unfamiliar field. Approximately 70 billion hours per year in the U.S. alone are spent on such complex information gathering tasks, and nearly all of that is lost, with no one else benefiting other than the individual searcher. My research aims to realize a distributed sensemaking cycle online, in which the mental models that individuals build while making sense of new domains are captured and made useful for others, rather than each person having to start from scratch.

A key challenge towards this vision is that people’s goals and knowledge may be too different to be useful to each other. For example, learning how to plant a garden in Pittsburgh would be very different from San Francisco. Indeed, we found that people would rather start from scratch than use the results of one other person’s search on the same topic. However, we hypothesized that if multiple people iterated on the same search topic, the useful high level structure of a domain would emerge while the more idiosyncratic information would drop out. Through a series of experiments in which we had people build and generate knowledge maps while searching, we found support for this hypothesis; e.g., in the garden example above, the plants you would use would differ but knowing about soil acidity and temperature zones would remain important. This work goes beyond previous approaches focusing on showing individual web pages that people popularly visit. Instead, we capture and surface the schemas that people synthesize across multiple web pages, and further demonstrate how these schemas can improve as more people are involved.

A crucial limitation to the above approach is the cold start problem. How can we get someone to iterate on a knowledge map if no one wants to start with a non-iterated map? To solve this problem, we developed a system that captures and aggregates the schemas of people independently learning a domain. Since people are working independently, we sidestep the iteration paradox, but raise the issue of whether more useful schemas will emerge from simple aggregation. Critically, we demonstrated that the most useful schemas were also the most commonly generated ones, and that idiosyncratic information still dropped out. Our system helped users to induce more useful, prototypical, and better-structured schemas than gathering information alone.

Another solution to the cold-start problem is to bootstrap information synthesis for a given topic such that users perceive there is already existing value for them to draw on. In our Knowledge Accelerator system we developed a computational system that can scaffold the entire process of information synthesis for a given topic, supporting an emerging interdependent, big picture view entirely through the small contributions of individuals each of whom sees only a part of the whole. The output of the system compared favorably to top information sources on the web, approaching or exceeding perceived quality ratings for even highly curated and reputable sources. Our work has had impact both in academia, where it has been cited as a key missing feature towards enabling collaborative search, and in industry, where it has inspired efforts to mine the messy but valuable information in forums and other unstructuredo online sources for a fraction of the cost of traditional expert-generated databases.

Taken together, this research opens up a new paradigm for information seeking online, in which the schemas that people build up while searching the web benefit those coming after them, changing the increasingly fragmented Web into one that is increasingly synthesized.
